> Here's how he picks the initial inputs:  In the initial population,
> for each member of the population, each input has a 1/(number of
> inputs) chance of being connected. 

And if it's picked to be connected, then it's fully connected - as per 
original NEAT? Sounds fair enough.

> Also the bias is always connected
> to the outputs.  So on average each network has the bias and one other
> input connected.  Any network with only the bias connected is forced
> to have one other connection connected.  So the initial population is
> minimal but diverse.

OK
 
> Here's another thing Shimon suggested:  Instead of training one big
> OCR network, train a separate network for each letter.  And do the
> training separately, i.e. an "is it a 'b'?" network and a separate "is
> it an 'a'?" network.

Intereting - it would cut down the size of the networks significantly - 
even fully connected networks would be feasable - even though I like the 
ideas of starting minimally.

However, this wouldn't work with my current demo, because it only inputs 
one image of each letter. I'd have to add alternative letters, either 
damaged "a":s or "a":s from other fonts.

Interestingly enough, it would be trivial to merge 26 such networks into 
a single network that solves all letters at once - why you would want to 
do that is unclear...

cheers,
m
